captions.text:
What’s crackin, B? This week we
gettin straight absurd with The Stranger by
Albert Camus.

My man Meursault ain’t trippin bout
the fact that his mama just died. Matter of

fact, this thug don’t seem to get bent over
much anything.

Meursault slides over to the beach
where he hollas at some fox he knew from back

when named Marie. Even though his mama only
been stiff fo’ twenty-fo’, Meursault don’t

waste no time slippin Marie his French baguette.
Know what I’m sayin?

Later she axe if he wanna get
married. And he all like “Sho baby. If you

want. Not like dem cuffs mean nuthin” Man..
You SHO pimpin ain’t easy?

Fo’ a lil’ while now, Meursault
been chillin with some mack-daddy named Raymond.

Thinkin his woman been actin a hoochie behind
his back, Ray-Ray gives her five across the
face and brings the law down on his ass.

With Meusault’s help, though, Ray-
ray shakes off the 5-0 and gets off scott

free. Thing is, the bro of Rad-diddy’s fine
lil’ peach jonezin for some STREET justice.

He and his Arab posse roll up on Ray-ray,
whip out their shiv and

SHANK him real good. Later, Meursault rolls
up on one of those A-rabs, takes a good long

look at his piece and realize that whether
he shoot or not, it don’t make a difference.

And once the sun’s hot- ass rays start doggin
our man, he whips out his glock and POP POP-
fool gets smoked.

Meursault gets thrown in the clink
and da law puts his ass on death row. But

it ain’t only cuz he 187- ed a fool. His
realest crime is bein a stranger to the rules

of society and not havin a heart like errybody
else.

Before Mersault bout to get tooken
out fo’ good, a chaplain drops in to give

him one last chance to embrace the big G-man.
All the sudden- Meursault SNAPS, gets all

in that preacher man’s grill and say “Look,
bitch. NOTHING MATTERS. I did some things

in life. I didn’t do other things. And none
of it matters.”

Right before he bout to snuff it,
our boy finds a lil’ peace in knowing FO

SHO that it’s all bout to end. And the universe
ain’t even gonna blink.

Damn man. This cat don’t seem to
give a sh** bout NOTHIN’. If a muthafu**in

meteor dropped down instantly icing a million
homies, this fool wouldn’t bat an eye. But
does him bein this hard make him a bad dude?

Truth is he ain’t bad or good. He
just different from the rest of us.

Day in day out, yo regular erryday
hood ain’t got the nuts to tussle with da

truth: life is meaningless, and what we do
or don't do, what does or doesn't happen to
us...none of it matters.

When we start bitchin and moanin
bout how good or bad somethin be, we really

just imposin order where it don't belong.
And when a homie who don’t play dat game
swangs in to town, he a stranger to errybody.

But even though ain’t nothin seem
to bother this hustla- a death sentence can

trip up even the hardest of hoods. When Meursault
starts marinating on meetin the man upstairs,

he flips sh** bout how these fools gonna ghost
him. To Meursault, the worst part bout it

is that there ain't NO CHANCE he gonna duck
the reaper:

And if you packin a big literary
dick, you know that my MAIN man Dostoevsky

droppin dat same angst 
in 
The Idiot:

What Meursault don't realize till
the end is that hopin to escape the machine

ain't no different than all those other bullsh**
lies that wankstas tell themselves on the

reg. There's only one way to roll like a big
dog in an indifferent world: with one hand

on yo nuts. Embrace that you ain't gonna escape
a damned thing, especially death. And when

yo time comes to dive six feet deep, ain't
nobody gonna give a damn.

Cept me, padna! Cuz I want you to
take yo hands off your nuts and hit dat subscribe
button! See you next week.

title: The Stranger - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Dane Thomas

comments.text:
Something really amazing about the way Camus wrote the_Stranger is how 
Mersualt remains such a debated protagonist. Not that the reader is unsure 
whether or not Mersualt committed the murder--to a discerning eye, it is 
even obvious that the murder was intentional; No,--the story renders the 
reader immobilized at condemning Mersault for his actions. The reader even 
grows to admire him for his inner-strength, no matter what what happens 
around him, Mersault remains equiposed; to this end He is portrayed 
statically, /ad hoc/ aloof. On top of that, you know that he killed a man 
involved in the murder of a good friend of his. Camus burdens the weight of 
judgement on the reader even more, when Mersault literally sleeps through 
his trial--what is he going to do, anyway?--He can't explain that in 
protecting his buddy from the *law,* dude got himself killed by the Arabian 
mafia!^1--He can't site his victim taunting him with the sunlight off the 
knife blade startling him and causing him to fire (hem-ha-hem, just 
prematurely) the gun--There is literally. Nothing. He can do. Lemon juice 
to open wound, when Mersault is brought up to the stand, the prosecutor 
attacks *his* morals for 'not mourning' his mother's death... Oh, the 
irony, that it is moral to condemn a man to a pitiless death for not 
appearing to mourn. (Subtly compounded accusation, as you may remember 
people at the funeral showing up just to... be seen there. Really.)﻿

comments.author: Joanne Z.

comments.text:
+Joanne Z. Hey why are you trying to stifle conversation? I think a great 
author like Camus does not need to be bound by continental philosophy or 
literary interpretations that rely on the historical accounts of what the 
author's work was about. Psychology now has become cognitive science. When 
Camus published the stranger Freud was barely in the ground. Of course our 
modern interpretations of character's motivations can be more clinical, we 
have clinical information. The author's intentions are not sacrosanct. 
Wanting to read the text as existentialist/absurdist is fine, but great art 
has a way of pointing at truths that are more tangible than non-positivist 
philosophy can handle. I think ignoring the naive realist reading, "Dude 
was psycho," or "Dude was cray cray," is doing a disservice to society's 
ability to assess why people break norms. His desire to escape death 
indicates that he is not purely rational being, or he would not have done 
something that would risk death in the first place.
comments.author: Kernel Sanders

comments.text:
+Caleb Horowitz I was talking about the comments not the video.He actually 
did an excellent job cramming it all into a four minute video.
comments.author: Joanne Z.

comments.text:
This is called "Thug Notes." It is four and a half minutes long. How would 
you expect him to give anything other than a simplification of the story? 
Sure, you can object to the use of the word 'psychopath' in particular, but 
anytime you're attempting to summarize and briefly analyze a work of 
literature, a few corners are going to get cut, a few complexities 
oversimplified...if it helps someone who didn't understand the novel at all 
previously get a moderately good grip on what's going on, the video has 
achieved its purpose. I totally agree with you, by the way, in regards to 
the mental state of the narrator, but I still think these kinds of videos 
can be excused for those kinds of mistakes and nonetheless be utilized as 
learning tools.

comments.text:
+Arizona Jonson​ You just committed a logical fallacy there.How did you 
miraculously jump to that conclusion? I never claimed that mental illnesses 
are reserved for "precious little children who don't mean any harm", 
explicitly OR implicitly.If you have studied the majority of Camus's 
ouevre,you'd be aware of the fact that mental illnesses were not 
essentially the subject of his interest.This novel has always been 
considered an existentialist/absurdist work ,which has come to form an 
entirely different branch of philosophy on its own, and has nothing to do 
with the said personality disorder.A MATURE reader and admirer of French 
literature would not try to diagnose the character with the term " 
psychopath" which has been ABUSED by pseudointellectuals who pretend to 
have a profound understanding of human nature.

comments.text:
also, just to add on, a quote I always think of when discussing The

comments.author: Aidin Murtha

comments.text:
Categorizing Meursault can be a bit difficult. At the end, most definitely, 
he has embraced an absurd lifestyle:

"As if the blind rage had washed me clean, rid me of hope; for the first 
time, in that night alive with signs and stars, I opened myself to the 
gentle indifference of the world. Finding it so much like myself - so like 
a brother, really- I felt that I had been happy and that I was happy 
again." (122-123)

Faced with his own mortality, Meursault truly recognizes the depth of his 
meaninglessness. He has long recognized the meainglessness of existence, 
going as far as to state that " everybody knows life isn't worth living '" 
(114), yet it is in certainity of death that this meaningless is resolved 
in a larger, universal context. He will have no impact, he will not be 
remembered, and this is the nature not just of his life, but of all things. 
This is the thought which comforts and brings catharsis to Meursault who 
has so long struggled with the futility of existence.

However, I would contest that Meursault is not nihilist at the beginning of 
the next. This is all tricky, though, as existentialism, existential 
nihilism (what we would be discussing in regards to Meursault), and 
absurdism all share common trends. However, in the earlier segments of The 
Stranger, Meursault is living in the existential void. He hasn't 
necessarily accepted that life has no inherent meaning or value, though he 
recognizes these as facets of existence. This fine difference between 
acceptance and recognition are significant, especially in the context of 
Meursault. He sees the pointlessness of life, yet he does not truly allow 
it to define him, rather, he struggles to exist as best he can with this 
knowledge, without the self-deception that everyone around him, from Marie 
to Raymond to the chaplain has, and without the resolution of this 
meaningless that comes with nihilism or absurdism.

As well, it's interesting to note how valuable the elements of his life he 
insisted to be meaningless are as the novel nears its conclusion:

"I said I had been looking at the stones in these walls for months . . . 
Maybe, at one time, way back, I had searched for a face in them. But the 
face I was looking for was as bright as the sun and the flame of desire - 
and it belonged to Marie."  (p. 119)
Several times, in transport from the courtroom to the prison van, he talks 
about the simplicity and happiness of his life when he could roam the 
streets, go for a swim, etc.
The last few chapters of the book are littered with stories from and 
allusions to his Maman.

Did he never love Marie, or did he simply dismiss the value of his emotions 
towards Marie due to is inability to comprehend this love in a world he 
understood was inescapably meaningless? Why does he so frequntly reference 
his Maman's thoughts/opinions now (and still use the intimate Maman in 
reference to her)? Why was he unable to recognize the value of these things 
prior to his imprisonment?

To reiterate, the answer is death. Meursaults existential crisis is 
assuaged by the threat of his execution which leads him to embrace the 
absurdity of existence. This is not a shift from a nihilist perspective to 
an absurd one. Rather, although Meursault was never plagued with the 
existential angst anticipated from the existential crisis, he has endured 
and escaped the void of meaning in which he lived throughout the novel.

I hope this helped in some way, and remember, you can disagree! That is the 
beauty of literature, I've only shared my opinions here.
comments.author: Aidin Murtha

comments.text:
You wisecrack me up,  my dear - Was just looking for a few ideas to help my 
daughter through her A level and came across your genius reviews - and 
relevant Dostoyevsky quote, the certainty of it! Ah you seriously made my 
day and I shall laugh myself to sleep tonight.....though I am still 
pondering on why Mersault wishes for a large crowd of spectators at his 
execution and that they greet him avec des cris de haine... 
pourquoi exactement ça?  Does it have anything to do with the memory of his 
father's reaction to an execution?  Is it just to juxtapose this scene of 
upheaval and distress to the state of total indifference and apparent 
serenity that immediately precedes it?  Probably just Camus' clever ending 
but this particular point's been bothering me a long long time.  Would love 
to hear you review John Williams' recently rediscovered great novels, 
Stoner, Augustus and especially the amazing Butcher's Crossing.  Bring it 
on Wisecrack!  ﻿

comments.text:
Love this channel! 

While the "Fall" is my personal favourite, "Outsider" is where it all 
started for me. 

What I love about Camus is that his idea of absurdity, the meaninglessness 
of existence, means that we are free - free to choose and create the 
meaning. Not to escape the void, but to embrace it and create the meaning. 

It is a very human way of approaching. Atheism in itself is just another 
"ism, a counter-religion that is simply a reaction to religion. But 
absurdity in Camus view? Now, that stands on its own. Neither against or 
for anything. ﻿

comments.text:
Camus brings up all sorts of questions in The Stranger, but it is up to the 
reader to wrestle with them.  Meursault is a nihilist, but Camus was 
writing in the absurdist vein here.  It is up to the reader to wrestle with 
he idea of murder and the extra shots fired and yet find Meursault still 
somewhat sympathetic with no hate in him.﻿

comments.text:
Why are people calling the protagonist a psychopath? He's just a realist, 
and if you want to use more specific philosophical terms, he's pretty much 
a nihilist. The world is meaningless, that's just a truth of existence, 
whether you want to lie to yourself or not, in the end, that's what 
remains. Emotions are the result of chemical reactions occurring every 
single second within your brain, they cloud logic, they make you feel as if 
there is a meaning to all of this, they try and add sense to it, and if you 
think that's wrong, and logic is what controls that function, then your 
logic is not correct. We're all just wandering sacks of flesh following 
down the same path, towards the end, without any reason, that's it and 
nothing else.﻿

This has one point to the Ideology of the Absurd, Yet it is only the first 
phase. After which understanding the knowledge that nothing will matter 
since all life will seize to exist, The present moments with the self is 
only what truly matters. Hence after the Idea of nothing be of worth is 
gone. The worth goes back to the self, in turn recreating the 
self as have worth in itself, which would create a worth in the spectacle 
that is life. (Which could be acknowledged or unacknowledged by the 
conscious). Which does recreate a worth with the understanding of 
eventual death.

comments.author: araceli

comments.text:
+Kinetic Vibe Nono I'm totally fine with nice arguments like these, but in 
all honesty that's exactly what I was trying to do: bring attention to 
other interpretations or ideas to explore for readers who might stumble 
upon this thread. I admit that my intial reply, in retrospect with dem all 
caps nonoes might've seemed 'too much', but saying that the significance of 
the sun is just that some people with low tolerance to heat can be 
influenced by it and the sun and that weather and other random elements 
etc. is not enough of an answer. So consider it as me adding onto your 
reply with other things to look at cause itd be a shame if people just took 
it at first level face value and didnt dig deeper. Notice how Meursault 
sounds bery trustworthy when he narrates and self-reflects but noticealso 
how subjective life is and that's when you realize that some denial 
might've been subtly inserted. Can't just take all the explicit and refuse 
to look for the implicit.
comments.author: NLperso

comments.text:

The Sun relates to death and is also associated with Meursault's dead 
mother. Where would you even begin? The OP asked "What is the significance 
of Camus always reminding us of how hot it is in the book" I realize time 
is precious but why leave a comment that leads to more questions than 
answers? Anyway I'm not hating or trying to argue I just don't know what 
you were trying to say.

+Kinetic Vibe Obviously! Apathy is THE main theme oof the book, hence the 
title The Stranger. But apathy involves emotion or the lack thereof and 
that's what I meant; those scenes relate to emotion, regardless of the 
protagonist's ability/choice of connecting with them or denying/repressing 
them.

comments.text:

comments.author: Cullen Welch

comments.text:
Camus said that "Meursault is the Christ we all deserve." 
There are a lot of interesting parallels between Meusault and Jesus in this 
book for sure, but the most interesting part of this book to me is when the 
prosecutor mentions charging Meursault with parricide. But when he killed 
the Arab, he didn't kill a father. He killed THE Father. Another 
interesting thing is how the book essentially takes place in a day. There's 
the morning with new life Marie and the ocean, then the hot afternoon with 
death, funerals and killings, and then the night for reflection. Gah, this 
book is so well thought out. Even if you can't agree with its message, you 
have to give it that.﻿

comments.author: Jessica Mahoney

comments.text:
The Stranger is the epitome of Western secular consciousness. No other 
culture in the world views life in such depressing, nihilistic terms. The 
idea of life being essentially meaningless seems to be unique to Western 
Civilization, as is the concept of atheism (Camus was an atheist). And The 
Stranger is a lousy, overrated book.﻿
comments.author: Tizoc Sagoyewatha

comments.text: Atheism and nihilism are not the same thing. At all. Please try again.
comments.author: bagamer13

comments.text:
The nihilistic view comes from the realization that there are things that 
are larger than man at play.  Do you concern yourself with the minds of 
ants?  It is only through this insignificance that we realize how small we 
really are, and because we are small, we fail to find meaning in an 
indifferent universe, whose forces concern themselves with things above the 
understanding and control of the insects we truly are.
